Anderson-type polyoxometalate as excellent catalyst for green synthesis of adipic acid with hydrogen peroxide Peng Jin a b c Huijuan Wei b ⁎ Limin Zhou b Donghui Wei b Yiqiang Wen b Bin Zhao b Xiangyu Wang b ⁎ Baojun Li b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Coking Coal Exploitation and Comprehensive Utilization, China Pingmei Shenma Group, Pingdingshan 467000, China State Key Laboratory of Coking Coal Exploitation and Comprehensive Utilization China Pingmei Shenma Group Pingdingshan 467000 China aState Key Laboratory of Coking Coal Exploitation and Comprehensive Utilization, China Pingmei Shenma Group, Pingdingshan 467000, China b Research Center of Green Catalysis, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China Research Center of Green Catalysis College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China bResearch Center of Green Catalysis, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China c Henan Shenma Catalytic Technology Co., Ltd., Pingdingshan 467000, China Henan Shenma Catalytic Technology Co., Ltd. The searching for novel catalysts is of importance for the industrial application of the green synthesis of adipic acid in the absence of toxic or dangerous oxidants or solvents. Herein, an Anderson-type polyoxometalate, [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4−, has been firstly employed as a highly effective oxidation catalyst for green synthesis of adipic acid with aqueous H2O2 as oxygen donor. Under the organic solvent- and phase-transfer catalyst-free conditions, excellent yields of adipic acid up to 95.6% and 90.9% could be obtained with cyclohexanediol and cyclohexene as substrates, respectively. Based on the spectroscopy characterization and density functional theory calculation, the detailed catalytic mechanism at the atomic level is proposed for this green catalytic synthesis method. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Anderson-type heteropolyanion, [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4-, has been firstly employed as a highly effective catalyst for the clean oxidation of cyclohexanediol and cyclohexene using hydrogen peroxide with excellent yields of adipic acid and quite little byproducts under organic solvent-, phase-transfer catalyst- and any other additive-free conditions. Keywords Catalysis Cyclohexanediol Cyclohexene Oxidation Polyoxometalate 1 Introduction Polyoxometalates (POMs) represent an emerging class of molecular systems and are especially valuable for catalysis, material science, biology, nanotechnology, magnetism and pharmaceuticals [1-18]. The Anderson-type heteropolyanions with the general formula [Hy(XO6)M6O18] n − (X is a transition-metal atom such as Co, Ni, Cr or Mn in a central octahedral cavity of the crown by edge-sharing six octahedral MO6 and M is MoVI or WVI), have received great interest because of their potential catalytic applications in selective oxidation [19-22]. When X is Ni or Co, Anderson-type heteropolyanions has been the efficient catalysts in the hydrodesulfurization reaction [20, 23-25]. Luo et al. has reported that single-atom Mn active site in a triol-stabilized beta-Anderson Manganohexamolybdate catalyzed the oxidation of cyclohexanone towards adipic acid [26]. In recent years, a large number of Anderson-type heteropolymolybdates have been reported [27-33]. However, there have been only few investigations about heteropolytungstates with Anderson-type structures in the literatures. The anion [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− is relatively well known about its structure and some thermal and catalytic properties among the Anderson-type heteropolytungstates [34-37]. With anion [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− as catalysts, some research on the catalytic performances in selective oxidation may be conducted. However, there only have been very few reports on the application of Anderson-type heteropolytungstates as catalysts for the selective oxidation of organic chemicals. As one of important industrial product synthesized from the catalytic oxidation processes, the adipic acid (ADA) is classically obtained by the catalytic oxidation of cyclohexanol or cyclohexanone using nitric acid as oxygen donor. The synthesis routine is detrimental to environment due to the formation of harmful nitrous oxide (N2O) [38]. Thus exploring the green synthesis method of ADA is extremely needed [39-42]. One preferred solution is using hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) for the catalytic oxidation synthesis of ADA and the exploration for novel high-performance catalysts is a research focus of this green route [43-47]. The acidity and oxidation capacity of catalysts are required for this green synthesis route. Keggin-type polyoxometalates as catalysts have been used in the ADA synthesis from liquid-phase oxidation, a ca. 76% yield of ADA has been achieved with H1Co1PMo12O40from cyclohexanone oxidation [48, 49]. Ren et al. has reported that ADA in high yield of 95.1% was synthesized from hydrogen peroxide oxidation of cyclohexene with heteropoly complexes and glycine as catalysts. [50] Anderson-type [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− possesses the appropriate acidity and oxidation capacity which could exhibit the superior catalytic performances [34]. The heteropolyanion [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− has never been reported as catalyst for synthesis of ADA. In this communication, the Anderson-type heteropolyanion, [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4−, was used to catalyze the clean oxidation of cyclohexene (CH) and cyclohexanediol (Diol) to ADA using H2O2 as oxidant. The excellent yields and selectivity to ADA were obtained under mild conditions. The mechanism of this catalytic system was suggested and Gibbs free energies calculated by density functional theory (DFT) method also support this proposed mechanism. 2 Experimental section 2.1 The preparation of catalysts Preparation of Na4[Ni(OH)6W6O18]•16H2O:[34, 37] 120 mL aqueous solution of sodium tungstate (30 g, 0.091 mol) was treated with 14 mol L − 1 nitric acid (6 mL, 84 mmol) at 85 °C under vigorously stirring until the precipitate formed dissolved entirely. Then 35 mL aqueous solution of nickel dichloride (5.5 g, 23 mmol) was added dropwise into the above solution under continuous stirring at 95 °C. After further 1–2 h at this temperature, the green turbid mixture was cooled to room temperature naturally. After filtration, the greenish blue clear solution was evaporated at 45 °C, the blue crystals appeared and they were washed repeatedly with distilled water, and dried in air. Crystallographic crystal data and structure processing parameters for Na4[Ni(OH)6W6O18]•16H2O are summarized in detail in Table S1. 2.2 The catalytic reaction The reaction was carried out in a round-bottomed flask with 250 mL. First, catalyst, substrate (cyclohexanediol or cyclohexene) and half of 17 wt% H2O2 was mixed under stirring. Then they were heated at the designed temperature and the reaction began. The residual half of 17 wt% H2O2 was added in ten batches every 30 min. The total molar ratio (catalyst: substrate: hydrogen peroxide) was 1: 80: 400 and 1.5: 80: 400 with cyclohexanediol and cyclohexene as substrate respectively. The resulting hot solution was collected and measured by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Agilent TCC18 reversed phase column, 25 cm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm particle size) with a UV detector and RID detector using a 30% methanol in 5 mM ammonium acetate buffer at pH 3.3 and 30 °C. UV data was collected at 225 nm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization and catalytic performance The combination of sodium tungstate, nitric acid and nickel dichloride in aqueous solution afforded a self-assembled compound with chemical formula Na4[Ni(OH)6W6O18]•16H2O as blue crystals. The single crystal diffraction (Table S1) and Fourier Transfer Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR, Fig. 1a) confirmed that this compound was an Anderson-type heteropolytungstate, which had the same components and structure as the reported compound [34]. Two areas of characteristic peaks at 880–730 and 880–910 cm−1 are attributed to stretching vibrations of W-O in W-O-W skeleton. The absorption band at 954 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibrations of terminal bonds W = O [37]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to study the nature of metal species on the surface of this blue crystals. The appearance of peaks at 854 and 872 eV are attributed to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 (Fig. 1d), the characteristic peaks at 35.4 and 37.6 eV are assigned to W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2 (Fig. 1e), respectively [51]. Under organic solvent-, phase-transfer catalyst- and any other additive-free conditions, Diol, catalyst and 17% H2O2 were introduced in a macro reactor, stirred and heated for designed time. Then, ADA with high purity was obtained, illustrated in Scheme 1 . The sandwich-type polyoxotungstate Na12[(WZn3(H2O)2] [(ZnW9O34)2]•46H2O was also investigated under our experimental conditions [52,53]. The effect of molar ratio of catalyst to Diol, reaction temperature and time on the catalytic performance have been investigated and shown in the Supporting information (Table S2, S3 and S4). In the optimal reaction condition, the ADA yields of 95.6% and 90.9% can be obtained from Diol with Anderson- and Sandwich-type heteropolyanion catalysts, respectively (Table 1 ). The yields of main byproduct glutaric acid (GA) are 1.5% and 4.2%, respectively; and the yields of another byproduct succinic acid (SA) are 1.3% and 1.7%, respectively (Table 1, entries 2–3). The controlled experiment shows that the only low yield of ADA is obtained with simple Na2WO4 as catalyst (Table 1, entry 1). To our surprise, when the cheap CH was used as substrate, the excellent yield of ADA can also be achieved by Anderson-type heteropolyanion catalyst (Table 1, entries 4–6). Although the reaction time is long, the catalyst is heteropolytungstate which is commonly considered as a no good catalyst or except for adding acidic additive, meanwhile, the pH environment is more mild than other systems that use H2WO4 H2O2, heteropoly acid-H2O2 or other strong acidic catalytic system for the effective synthesis of ADA. These experimental results show that [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− is an excellent catalyst for the clean synthesis of ADA with very high ADA yield and quite little byproducts less than previous reported catalyst systems. Moreover, the pH of catalyst solution (Table 1, entries 1–3 or 4–6) mixed with H2O2 are 8.1, 4.2 and 6.7, respectively. The pH trend of catalyst systems is agreement with that of catalytic performance. The lower pH of the catalyst provides the better performance. For the Anderson-type polyoxotungstate (Fig. 2 a), the cyclic voltammetry (CV) is quite straightforward. An irreversible peak at 252 mV is observed, which could be attributed to a W(V)→W(VI) transition. In the case of Sandwich-type polyoxotungstate (Fig. 2b), the irreversible peak at −870 mV is similar with the literature, which should also be attributed to oxidation of W(V)→W(VI) [54]. This potential is substantially lower than that of Anderson-type polyoxotungstate, which indicates that the Anderson-type polyoxotungstate possesses a stronger oxidative capacity. Interestingly, the Anderson-type polyoxotungstate provides better catalytic reaction results (Table 1), thus the oxidative potential should be considered as the other important parameter of oxidation catalyst. The FTIR spectrum of [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− indicates the structure is in consistent with the literature (Fig. 1a, i) [34, 51]. After addition of H2O2 (Fig. 1a, ii), the peak at 904 cm−1 disappear and a new small peak at 816 cm−1 typically attributed to formation of the peroxo species appear, which is also evidenced by the disappearance of Raman shift peak at 903 cm−1(Fig. 1b). After (ii) was treated by KBr, the FTIR spectrum is then almost again identical to that of fresh [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4- (Fig. 1a, iii). The spectroscopic results indicate that the [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− is solvolytically stable to aqueous H2O2. The consistent UV–vis spectra demonstrate the structure stability of the WO6 octahedrons (Fig. 1c). The highly stable CV curves provide further evidence for the stability of [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− in the redox processes (Fig. 1d). 3.2 Formation mechanism The mechanism involved six reaction steps (Fig. 3 ) has been proposed for the generation of ADA with cyclohexene as substrate [39]. Simplified peroxy tungsten compound was used as catalyst model to study the six steps of the proposed reaction mechanism [55-59]. The geometry structures of reactants, intermediates and product have been optimized at the B3LYP/6–31 G (d, p) level and Δ G of each step are shown in Fig. 4 . The first step is olefin epoxidation reaction, and the theoretical calculation results of this step mechanism are listed in Fig. 4[1] [60-62]. It is generally believed that catalysts are needed in the epoxidation of olefin. In this step, peroxy tungsten compound first gets access to cyclohexene to form intermediate M1–1, then M1–1 produces cyclohexene oxide and C2 via TS1–1. Δ G are −73.40 and 0.15 kcal/mol, so it is spontaneous. The second step is the hydrolysis reaction of epoxides and it is an acid catalytic reaction [63]. Hydrogen ion reacts with cyclohexene oxide to produce intermediate M2–1, then water molecular attacks M2–1 to form M2–2, M2–2 generates intermediate M2–3 crossing the transition state TS2–1(Fig. 4[2]), finally cyclohexanediol is obtained by the loss of a hydrogen ion for M2–3. Δ G values are also low that this step reaction is easy to proceed. The third step is the oxidation of a hydroxyl group in cyclohexanediol to a carbonyl group [64]. one hydroxyl of cyclohexanediol interacts with peroxy tungsten compound to form intermediate M3–1, then M3–1 is restructured to M3–2 through TS3–1. Finally, 2-hydroxycyclohexan-1-one (P3 ) is obtained by the loss of a water and C2 molecule for the intermediate M3–2 through TS3–2. The lower ΔG (−39.93, 1.82 and −12.53 kcal mol−1) of this step is beneficial to keep the reaction going. The fourth step is Baeyer-Villiger oxidation reaction and the relative DFT study on the mechanisms of tungsten-catalyzed Baeyer-Villiger reaction using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant has been reported by our group [59]. ΔG of each process are negative and it indicate that the peroxo tungsten compound would play an important role in making the reaction easier to occur. The fifth step is the oxidation of another hydroxyl group of cyclohexanediol to carbonyl group [64]. The reaction process is similar to Step 3. P4 reacts with the peroxy species to generate M5–3 via two transition states (TS5–1 and TS5–2), and then M5–3 loses a water and C2 molecular to generate P5 . The overall ΔG is favorable for the formation of P5 . The last step is the hydrolysis of anhydride [65]. P5 is hydrolyzed into ADA by water, and this is also an energetically favorable reaction. The regeneration mechanism of catalyst have been studied using density functional theory (DFT) method in our previous work [59]. In the above six steps, 1, 3, 4 and 5 are mainly oxidation reaction and 2, 4 is an acid-catalyzed reaction. Based on this mechanism, the catalyst possessing both acidity and oxidation capacity is required, [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4− catalyst has the appropriate acidity and oxidation capacity, thus it displays the superior catalytic performances (Table 1). 4 Conclusions In summary, the Anderson-type POM, [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4−, has been firstly used as effective oxidation catalyst for green synthesis of ADA by aqueous H2O2. Under any other additive-free condition, almost 100% of conversion is achieved with high selectivity (>95.5%) to ADA, along with quite little byproducts. This work points out a novel catalysis application of Anderson-type POM, which exhibits immense potential in the catalytic oxidation fields. coredata.dc:description: The searching for novel catalysts is of importance for the industrial application of the green synthesis of adipic acid in the absence of toxic or dangerous oxidants or solvents. Herein, an Anderson-type polyoxometalate, [Ni(OH)6W6O18]4−, has been firstly employed as a highly effective oxidation catalyst for green synthesis of adipic acid with aqueous H2O2 as oxygen donor. Under the organic solvent- and phase-transfer catalyst-free conditions, excellent yields of adipic acid up to 95.6% and 90.9% could be obtained with cyclohexanediol and cyclohexene as substrates, respectively. Based on the spectroscopy characterization and density functional theory calculation, the detailed catalytic mechanism at the atomic level is proposed for this green catalytic synthesis method.
coredata.dc:title: Anderson-type polyoxometalate as excellent catalyst for green synthesis of adipic acid with hydrogen peroxide
